Posts.Content: KateHP wrote: Hi Everyone -   I went on Thursday for a core needle biopsy which was recommended after an US showed an abnormaility a couple of weeks ago.  I had decided to stay local for the biopsy instead of traveling into Boston because I didn't think it would be a big deal.  Now I'm not so sure.   The nurse who was doing the US had difficulty finding the lump.  The original nurse who found the lump had no trouble whatsoever.  After about 10 minutes of her searching, she took some pictures, but I don't think they were in quite the same place the other lump had been.  When the doctor came in, it took her a few minutes to find the lump again on US.  The doctor then noted it wasn't as wide as it had been documented in the original report and that it wasn't exactly in the same spot.  They looked briefly to where it had been noted in the original report, but they didn't see anything.  I noticed the nurse wasn't pushing down as hard when she was doing the US.  I don't know if that would make a difference with a very small lump (less than 1 cm) in a very dense breast?   Anyways, they took the biopsy of whatever they did see, and I find out the results in a week.   But I'm really nervous they didn't biopsy the right lump.  If the results come back negative, should I head into Boston for a 2nd opinion anyway?  I don't think my insurance would cover another US or mammogram right now, but maybe they would order an MRI?  I'm just not confident in what happened on Thursday.  The whole time I was thinking, "I should have went to Boston."    Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2011 11:34PM KateHP wrote: Special K - They did leave a clip marker.  I didn't know that would show up on Ultrasounds.  Good to know!  So if another ultrasound is done, they'll be able to see if they did, in fact, biopsy the right spot? I find out my results on Thursday, but I also scheduled an appointment at MGH for the following week.  Even if it is nothing, I want to get evaluated there each year.  I'm at moderate risk for developing breast cancer.  I've watched both of my aunts suffer from this, and one lose her battle.  I want to do everything I can to prevent this or detect it early.   I'm a teacher and head back to school in just a couple of weeks.  This all couldn't have come at a worse time.  Getting to appointments isn't easy once there are a classroom full of kids to teach.
